instruction: How were the machine learning models utilized in the related study on mapping arable field areas in sub-Saharan agroecosystems?
Output:
In the related study, machine learning models were utilized to map arable field areas in sub-Saharan agroecosystems. The researchers employed a Random Forest classifier, which is a supervised learning algorithm, to perform the mapping task. The classifier was trained using over 300,000 samples and employed a 10-fold cross-validation technique for model evaluation.

To build the model, the researchers first conducted feature selection using recursive feature elimination. Out of the initial 137 image features, only 11 features were found to be important for the classification task. These features included Sentinel-2 SWIR-based spectral features, Sentinel-1 polarimetric (VV) features, and elevation features. Half of the important features were variance texture features, while the rest were spectral features.

The Random Forest classifier achieved a 0.78 AUC (Area Under the Curve) score, indicating its ability to discriminate between arable and non-arable areas. The overall precision, recall, and F1-score of the model were 0.96, 0.78, and 0.85, respectively. The precision for both classes (arable and non-arable) was above 0.90, indicating a high level of accuracy in classifying the areas.
